segment.source: Repair a Windows Image
segment.target: Repair a Windows Image

segment.source: Repair a Windows Image
segment.target: Repair a Windows Image

segment.source: Repair a Windows Image
segment.target: Repair a Windows Image

segment.source: Repair a Windows image using DISM.
segment.target: Repair a Windows image using DISM.

segment.source: You can repair offline Windows image in a WIM or VHD file, or an online Windows image.
segment.target: You can repair offline Windows image in a WIM or VHD file, or an online Windows image.

segment.source: An online Windows image will also attempt to repair itself if it becomes unserviceable.
segment.target: An online Windows image will also attempt to repair itself if it becomes unserviceable.

segment.source: The repair source for this operation is the same source that is used for Features on Demand and is determined by Group Policy settings.
segment.target: The repair source for this operation is the same source that is used for Features on Demand and is determined by Group Policy settings.

segment.source: For more information, see Configure a Windows Repair Source.
segment.target: For more information, see Configure a Windows Repair Source.

segment.source: When you use the DISM tool to repair an online or offline image, you can use the /Source argument with the /RestoreHealth argument to specify additional repair source locations to use to search for the required files.
segment.target: When you use the DISM tool to repair an online or offline image, you can use the /Source argument with the /RestoreHealth argument to specify additional repair source locations to use to search for the required files.

segment.source: For a quick check of an online image, you may be able to use the command: to scan and repair files.
segment.target: For a quick check of an online image, you may be able to use the command: to scan and repair files.

segment.source: For a more extensive check that can repair issues with the store, use .
segment.target: For a more extensive check that can repair issues with the store, use .

segment.source: To check if an image is repairable
segment.target: To check if an image is repairable

segment.source: Scan the image to check for corruption.
segment.target: Scan the image to check for corruption.

segment.source: This operation will take several minutes.
segment.target: This operation will take several minutes.

segment.source: For example, at a command prompt, type the following command:
segment.target: For example, at a command prompt, type the following command:

segment.source: Check the image to see whether any corruption has been detected.
segment.target: Check the image to see whether any corruption has been detected.

segment.source: For example, at a command prompt, type:
segment.target: For example, at a command prompt, type:

segment.source: When you use the /CheckHealth sfc argument, the DISM tool will report whether the image is healthy, repairable, or non-repairable.
segment.target: When you use the /CheckHealth sfc argument, the DISM tool will report whether the image is healthy, repairable, or non-repairable.

segment.source: If the image is non-repairable, you should discard the image and start again.
segment.target: If the image is non-repairable, you should discard the image and start again.

segment.source: If the image is repairable, you can use the /RestoreHealth argument to repair the image.
segment.target: If the image is repairable, you can use the /RestoreHealth argument to repair the image.

segment.source: To repair an image
segment.target: To repair an image

segment.source: Use the /RestoreHealth argument to repair the image.
segment.target: Use the /RestoreHealth argument to repair the image.

segment.source: For example, to repair an offline image using a mounted image as a repair source, at a command prompt, type the following command:
segment.target: For example, to repair an offline image using a mounted image as a repair source, at a command prompt, type the following command:

segment.source: Or to repair an online image using some of your own sources instead of Windows Update, type:
segment.target: Or to repair an online image using some of your own sources instead of Windows Update, type:

segment.source: If you do not specify a /Source for the repair files, the default location for Features on Demand is used.
segment.target: If you do not specify a /Source for the repair files, the default location for Features on Demand is used.

segment.source: For more information, see Configure a Windows Repair Source.
segment.target: For more information, see Configure a Windows Repair Source.

segment.source: If you specify more than one /Source, the files are copied from the first location where they are found and the rest of the locations are ignored.
segment.target: If you specify more than one /Source, the files are copied from the first location where they are found and the rest of the locations are ignored.

segment.source: You can use /LimitAccess to prevent the DISM tool from using Windows Update as a repair source or as a backup repair source for online images.
segment.target: You can use /LimitAccess to prevent the DISM tool from using Windows Update as a repair source or as a backup repair source for online images.

segment.source: Repairing images during servicing
segment.target: Repairing images during servicing

segment.source: In some cases, an image can be corrupted while modifying it with DISM.
segment.target: In some cases, an image can be corrupted while modifying it with DISM.

segment.source: Use /Cleanup-MountPoints to repair it.
segment.target: Use /Cleanup-MountPoints to repair it.

segment.source: This command will not unmount images that are already mounted, nor will it delete images that can be recovered using the /Remount-Image command.
segment.target: This command will not unmount images that are already mounted, nor will it delete images that can be recovered using the /Remount-Image command.
